organization.$: Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering

head.citation-title: Automatic target recognition in SAR images using quaternion wavelet transform and principal component analysis
head.abstracts: Copyright © 2017 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.Automatic target recognition (ATR) is the task of classifying sensed imagery from synthetic aperture radar (SAR) automatically into a canonical set of target classes. Here, a method to recognise different classes of military vehicles based on the combination of quaternionic wavelet transform (QWT) and principal component analysis (PCA) features is presented. To identify the certain region of SAR images, patches are extracted over the interest points detected from the SAR images. Then QWT features and PCA features are computed and combined for every patch. These extracted features are trained and classified using SVM. The performance of QWT is compared with two more multiresolution transforms such as ridgelet transform and log Gabor transform as well as the Scale and rotationinvariant interest point detector and descriptor, named speeded up robust features (SURF). Observations revealed that QWT outperforms the ridgelet transform, log-Gabor and SURF. The experimental evaluation is done using the MSTAR database.

organization.$: Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering

translated-sourcetitle.$: International Journal of Computational Vision and Robotics

source.sourcetitle: International Journal of Computational Vision and Robotics

grant-text.$: We express our sincere thanks to the College Management, Principal and Head of the Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Mepco Schlenk Engineering College, Sivakasi, for providing us all the facilities and support to carry out this research work. Authors thank Prof. Raphael Soulard, XLIM-SIC Laboratory, University of Poitiers, France for his support in implementing the algorithm of QWT. The authors would like to thank Sandia National Laboratory (SNL) SAR sensor platform, for the collection of MSTAR data at the Redstone Arsenal, US Army, Huntsville, AL.

Observations revealed that QWT outperforms the ridgelet transform, log-Gabor and SURF. The experimental evaluation is done using the MSTAR database.
